docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You report that doctors at health maintenance organizations sometimes ignore contract provisions that inhibit doctor-patient communication, in fear that patients will sue them for malpractice if they do not disclose all treatment options (news article, Sept. 25). But recent court decisions give little basis for such fears. In Rust v. Sullivan, the United States Supreme Court upheld the Government's policy of enforcing silence about abortion as a method of family planning when doctors accept Federal money.

headline.main: Courts Back H.M.O.'s Over Doctor Honesty

docs.abstract: Anthony Lew letter responds to Sept 19 article on decreasing number of AIDS diagnoses and deaths in US; contends that it is unwise to consider drug therapy reliable future method of AIDS prevention

docs.lead_paragraph: Three big health maintenance organizations joined two consumer groups today in calling for more regulation of managed health care, saying all health plans should be subject to ''legally enforceable national standards.'' Such standards, they said, are essential to restore confidence in the health care system, which has been eroded by reports from many H.M.O. patients that they have had difficulty getting the care they need.

headline.main: 3 Big Health Plans Join in Call for National Standards

docs.abstract: Three big nonprofit health maintenance organizations, Kaiser Permanente, HIP Health Insurance Plans and Group Health Cooperative of Puget Sound, join two consumer groups, Families USA and American Association of Retired People, in calling for legally enforceable national standards for managed health care; cite erosion of confidence in health care system caused by reports from many HMO patients that they have trouble getting needed care (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: F.T.C. Is Investigating Intel's Business Practices Chip maker Intel said that the Federal Trade Commission has begun an investigation of the company's business practices. The investigation is separate from an inquiry under way by the commission regarding Intel's proposed acquisition of Chips & Technologies Inc. [Page D2.]
docs.snippet: F.T.C. Is Investigating Intel's Business Practices  Chip maker Intel said that the Federal Trade Commission has begun an investigation of the company's business practices.     The investigation is separate from an inquiry under way by the commission...

docs.lead_paragraph: Thalidomide, the drug whose use in the 1960's produced thousands of babies with flipperlike arms and other gross deformities, is on the verge of receiving approval from the Food and Drug Administration, nearly four decades after the agency's legendary decision to reject it for use in the United States. Officials at the agency announced today that they intended to approve thalidomide for use in leprosy patients, as long as the New Jersey-based company seeking to market it could adhere to several conditions, including elaborate restrictions intended to keep the drug away from women who are or might become pregnant.

headline.main: 37 YEARS LATER, A SECOND CHANCE FOR THALIDOMIDE

docs.abstract: Thalidomide, drug which caused widespread birth defects in 1960's and was rejected for use in US, is on verge of Federal approval for treatment of leprosy, nearly four decades after it was banned; officials say they will approve use as long as manufacturer, Celgene Corp, adheres to several conditions, including elaborate restrictions intended to keep it away from women who are or might become pregnant; drug has been experiencing revival of sorts in recent years, and scientists are experimenting with it for treatment of variety of ailments; company spokesman Dr Murray Lumpkin comments (M)
